What most people overlook is that Megalodon gave birth to live young that  were 5 to 6 feet (or there about) in length and these had to compete for the same food as White sharks in similar environments; this was their Achilles heel, so to speak. Being big as an adult isn't of itself, protection as a species. So as the adult Meg's food became more difficult to obtain (Whales spent more time in colder waters it is believed) this combined with the pressure Great Whites exerted upon the Meg's young both competing for food the same food items and even killing these smaller Meg's as food, likely combined to kill off the Meg's. Aside: yes, Great Whites had young but these were much smaller then Meg's pup's. As such, these very small Whites would eat a food source (small fish for instance) that larger Whites didn't generally pursue nor did the young of the Meg (not worth the effort for return on energy invested.) So, White's young had fewer other species competing for its food source.
Whilst we may not know much about the daily life of Otodus megalodon, we know a great deal about the daily life of the citizens of Pompei. It's called 'history'.

I kind of resent the way you say understanding Roman DNA is the closest thing we'll have to a time machine. I'm sure there are plenty of interesting things that DNA data can help us confirm or disprove, but in general there is a certain obsession of DNA that I really hate, that I think you're comment feeds into. First of all, as a student of linguistics & anthropology, I know that culture is not found in DNA. The beliefs, practices, daily life, the vast, vast majority of the experience of an ancient Roman, that's not in their DNA.

The thing DNA can help us understand is the movement of people groups, and even that is not perfect. For example a lot of people in Hokkaidō Japan, fascinated by the native Ainu culture, wonder what their roots are, where they come from, especially when compared to the "wajin" or majority culture of Japan whose language traces to the Yamato people of Honshū. Often, I've heard people talking about this or that genetic study that says Ainu are related to this or that central Asian group, or to no other modern group, etc, and I kind of hate it. The genetics of the Ainu tell us NOTHING about who they are. Talking about DNA ends up being this racialist mentality where DNA is seen as deterministic of what kind of human, what kind of culture you are. Language and culture can and have throughout history transcended genetics. If one group subsumes another, genetically distinct one, the dominant group's language & culture will spread into it. Language and cultural complexes can spread just through trade and prestige, all these sorts of things. What the genes of the Ainu tell us about who their ancestors are related to, on it's own, tell us very little really about the Ainu.

We know from Archeology & anthropology though, that there were people participating in a form of Jōmon culture in prehistoric Hokkaidō, then developed into a distinct cultural complex called the Satsumon culture, while another cultural complex the Okhotsk culture, seems to have come in from outside Hokkaidō (from the north), and brought in many elements we see in the later Ainu culture, such as bear worship. The Ainu are undoubtedly influences by all these stages, but which one brought in their language? We know that the Okhotsk culture had the more visible influence on the Ainu culture, but genetics tell us that Ainu are around 50% derived from the Satsumon culture, and only 22% from the Okhotsk, according to recent study * . This genetic data point is interesting, but it is not the whole story. Okhotsk culture may have had more power and influence and their language became dominant, giving us Ainu, or maybe Ainu was the language of the Satsumon culture, a descendant of some form of Jōmon language, and just borrowed a lot from the influential Okhotsk culture. DNA can't answer these questions, not alone anyway.

* https://academic.oup.com/gbe/article/13/9/evab192/6355032?login=false
